justification: The article states, “Inhibition control is a fundamental cognitive process… From the restraint observed in the stop-signal paradigm (Logan, 1994)… inhibition control plays a central role in decision-making,” directly tying the construct to the stop-signal task as its measure.

The same sentence notes inhibition control is revealed when “identifying targets amidst distractors in the flanker paradigm (Eriksen & Eriksen, 1974),” indicating the flanker task is another instrument used to measure this construct.

The authors explain they will test model predictions with “event-related potentials (ERPs), particularly the centro-parietal potential (CPP), which has been associated with the decision variable in the classic decision-diffusion model (DDM) (Twomey et al., 2015).”

Under Materials, the article describes “The road-crossing task simulated a first-person perspective scenario, where participants acted as pedestrians about to cross a road,” showing that the computerized task operationalizes (measures) the construct of road-crossing decisions.
